review.title: Detecting Context Dependence in Exercise Item Candidates Selected from Corpora
review.abstract: We explore the factors influencing the dependence of single sentences on their larger textual context in order to automatically identify candidate sentences for language learning exercises from corpora which are presentable in isolation. An in-depth investigation of this question has not been previously carried out. Understanding this aspect can contribute to a more efficient selection of candidate sentences which, besides reducing the time required for item writing, can also ensure a higher degree of variability and authenticity. We present a set of relevant aspects collected based on the qualitative analysis of a smaller set of context-dependent corpus example sentences. Furthermore, we implemented a rule-based algorithm using these criteria which achieved an average precision of 0.76 for the identification of different issues related to context dependence. The method has also been evaluated empirically where 80% of the sentences in which our system did not detect context-dependent elements were also considered context-independent by human raters.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Extracting individual sentences from corporations using Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools can be useful for a number of purposes, including identifying candidate sentences for the automatic generation of exercises. Such sentences are also known as seed sentences (Sumita et al., 2005) or carrier sentences (Smith et al., 2010) in intelligent computerized language teaching (ICALL). Interest in using corpora in language teaching began as early as the 1980s, as the increasing amount of digital texts available enables learning through authentic language usage (O'Keeffe et al., 2007). However, since sentences in a text form constitute a coherent discourse, it may be necessary to interpret certain expressions in a sentence, i.e., a context that is needed to determine a context (O'Keeffe et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Corpus Examples Combined with NLP for Language Learning
sections.text: In a language learning scenario, sample sentences can be useful both as exercise elements and as vocabulary examples. Previous work on creating exercise elements has applied different strategies for selecting carrier sentences. In some cases, sentences are mainly required to include a lexical element or linguistic pattern that is the goal of the exercise, but context dependence is not explicitly addressed (Sumita et al., 2005; Arregik, 2011). Another alternative was the use of dictionary examples as carrier sentences, e.g. from WordNet (Pino and Eskenazi, 2009). Such sentences are inherently context-independent, but represent some limitations on the linguistic aspects to be pursued in the exercises. In Pila ́ n et al. (2014) we have presented and compared two algorithms for selecting carrier sentences in Swedish, using both rule-based and machine learning methods.

sections.heading: 2.2 Linguistic Aspects Influencing Context Dependence
sections.text: The relationship between sentences in a text can be expressed either explicitly or implicitly, i.e. with or without specific linguistic elements that require extrasentential information (Mitkov, 2014). The explicit forms include words and phrases that imply structural discourse relationships or are anaphorical (Webber et al., 2003). In a text, the way sentences are linked together can have an additional relational meaning in addition to that which we can deduce separately from the content of each sentence. Examples of such elements include structural connectives: conjunctions, conjunctions, and "paired" conjunctions (Webber et al., 2003). Another form of reference to aforementioned discourses is anaphora. The phenomenon anaphora consists of a word or phrase (anaphora) that refers to a previously mentioned entity (antecedent). Mitkov (2014) outlines a number of different anaphora functions that are most common based on their location and anaphora.

sections.heading: 3 Datasets
sections.text: In fact, it is that we are able to assert ourselves, that we are able, that we are able to hide ourselves, and that we are able, that we will be able, that we will be able, that we will be able, that we will be able.

sections.heading: 4 Methodology
sections.text: In fact, most people who see themselves as capable are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they don't want.

sections.heading: 5 Data Analysis Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Qualitative Results Based on Thematic Analysis
sections.text: The list of topics collected during our qualitative analysis is long.

sections.heading: 5.2 Quantitative Comparison of Positive and Negative Samples
sections.text: In addition to conducting a thematic analysis, we also compared our positive and negative samples based on quantitative linguistic information in search of additional evidence for the topics that arose and to identify other aspects that were potentially worth targeting. Overall, the language frequency count (POS) showed some large differences between CDEP and CINDEP sentences. There was a tendency toward a nominal content in context-dependent sentences, where 21.6% of all POS tags were nouns. However, this value was 9% lower for context-dependent sentences, suggesting a preference for a higher density of concepts in context-dependent sentences. In contrast, pronouns in context-dependent sentences were more common (12.6% overall) than in context-independent sentences (7% less common). Qualitative analysis found that elements responsible for context-dependence often occurred at the beginning of the sentence. Therefore, we compared the three-set of three-quarter sentences to the initial tendency of these two sets, with only a percentage of the three-second groups matching the initial tendency of each of the two.

sections.heading: 6 An Algorithm for the Assessment of Context Dependence
sections.text: This year, it has reached the point where it will be able to retaliate until it is able to retaliate.

sections.heading: 7 Performance on the Datasets
sections.text: We evaluated our system both on the hand-picked negative examples collected by EVAL1 and EVAL2 (CDEP) and on the positive examples emanating from the good dictionaries (CINDEP-D.) The performance in predicting various aspects of context dependence is presented in the table. We focused on maximizing precision, i.e. correctly identifying as many topics as possible in the hand-picked CDEP sentences, aiming to avoid each context-dependent sentence rather than retrieving them all.

sections.heading: 8 User-based Evaluation Results
sections.text: The evaluation data consisted of 3383 sentences retrieved from a large number of modern Swedish corpora and classified as non-context sentences according to our algorithm (with the exception of 4 control sentences that were context-dependent), all of which were invisible sentences that were not present in the data sets described in Section 3. In the evaluation structure, all implemented topics were used as filters, i.e. sentences that contained a recognised element associated with context dependence were discarded. In addition to context dependence, other selection criteria (e.g. readability) were included in the evaluation system, but for reasons of relevance and space, these aspects and the associated results were not discussed. The selected sentences were given to 5 language teachers who assessed the suitability of these sentences according to 3 criteria: (i) their degree of context independence, (ii) their CE4 and FRi level (in total two sentences were required for their ability to learn).

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Based on the thematic analysis of a number of context-based sentences, we implemented a rules-based algorithm to automatically assess this aspect, which was evaluated not only on the basis of our data sets, but also with the help of language teachers with very positive results. Approximately 76% of the subjects were correctly identified in context-based sentences, while the number of misalignments in the context-independent data remained rather low. Approximately 80% of the candidate sentences selected with a system that incorporates the presented algorithm were classified as context-dependent in our user-based assessment, and the results also showed a positive correlation between context-independent and overall language learning tendencies. In the future, we plan to investigate the extension of the algorithm to other languages and to experiment with machine learning approaches for this task, including the resources mentioned in this paper.

Identifying corpus examples for illustrating lexical items is the main purpose of the GDEX (Good Dictionary Examples) algorithm (Husák, 2010; Kilgarriff et al., 2008) which has also inspired a Swedish algorithm for sentence selection (Volodina et al.

In Pilán et al. (2014) we presented and compared two algorithms for carrier sentence selection for Swedish, using both rule-based and machine learning methods.

Identifying corpus examples for illustrating lexical items is the main purpose of the GDEX (Good Dictionary Examples) algorithm (Husák, 2010; Kilgarriff et al., 2008) which has also inspired a Swedish algorithm for sentence selection (Volodina et al., 2012). GDEX incorporates a number of linguistic criteria (e.g. sentence length, vocabulary frequency) based on which example candidates are ranked. Some of these are related to context dependence (e.g. incompleteness of sentences, presence of personal pronouns), but they are somewhat coarser-grained criteria not focusing on syntactic aspects. A system using GDEX for carrier sentence selection is described in Smith et al. (2010) who underline the importance of the well-formedness of a sentence and who determine a sufficient amount of context in terms of sentence length.

Another phenomenon connected to context dependence is gapping where the second mention of a linguistic element is omitted from a sentence (Poesio et al., 2011).

One of the characteristics of such sentences is the absence of referring expressions which would require a larger context to be understood (Kilgarriff et al., 2008), therefore they can be considered suitable representatives of context-independent sentences.
We collected instances of good dictionary example sentences from two Swedish lexical resources: SALDO (Borin et al., 2013) and the Swedish FrameNet (SweFN) (Heppin and Gronostaj, 2012).

We collected instances of good dictionary example sentences from two Swedish lexical resources: SALDO (Borin et al., 2013) and the Swedish FrameNet (SweFN) (Heppin and Gronostaj, 2012). Sentences explicitly considered dependent on a larger context are less available due to their lack of usefulness in most application scenarios. metadata.abstractText: We explore the factors influencing the dependence of single sentences on their larger textual context in order to automatically identify candidate sentences for language learning exercises from corpora which are presentable in isolation. An in-depth investigation of this question has not been previously carried out. Understanding this aspect can contribute to a more efficient selection of candidate sentences which, besides reducing the time required for item writing, can also ensure a higher degree of variability and authenticity. We present a set of relevant aspects collected based on the qualitative analysis of a smaller set of contextdependent corpus example sentences. Furthermore, we implemented a rule-based algorithm using these criteria which achieved an average precision of 0.76 for the identification of different issues related to context dependence. The method has also been evaluated empirically where 80% of the sentences in which our system did not detect context-dependent elements were also considered context-independent by human raters.
